citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
During the routine inspection, the facility representatives told inspectors that they have not been able to confirm the status
of one of the female wolves. They reported they were planning to go in that morning and look for it about the time we
arrived. The facility representative reported that the adult wolf had been last seen running along the back of the enclosure
fence during afternoon feeding on Friday, 10/18. On Saturday, 10/19, and Sunday, 10/20, the facility representatives did
not observe the wolf during their daily observation checks. On Saturday, 10/19, the licensee determined Monday, 10/21,
would be safer to enter the wolf enclosure to look closer for the wolf as the enclosure doesn't have a lockout for the
remaining wolf and they would need a staff member to assist watching the remaining wolf while another person looked.
On Monday morning, 10/21, the female wolf again was not seen and they still planned to look for it. During the inspection,
the facility representatives reported they entered the enclosure, observing dens and checking the enclosure fence. They
reported they didn't find the wolf and also walked the entire enclosure fence and did not find any areas that indicated it got
out. We also observed around the entire enclosure and did not find any areas that would indicate escape. However, the
second wolf was unable to be located. The facility representatives noted that there was an area in the center of the
enclosure that could not be observed thoroughly without proper equipment or clearing some of the brush. At the time of
the exit interview the licensee stated that 3 facility representatives were currently working on removing brush and looking
for the second wolf.
The lack of ability to confirm an animal's status with a daily observation of the animal doesn't guarantee if the animal is in
good condition. Correct by ensuring enclosures are equipped with the ability to observe animals and/or coordinate with
employees in a timely fashion to confirm that animals are in good health.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
SCOTT WELCH, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
During the routine inspection, the facility representatives told inspectors that they have not been able to confirm the status 
of one of the female wolves. They reported they were planning to go in that morning and look for it about the time we 
arrived. The facility representative reported that the adult wolf had been last seen running along the back of the enclosure 
fence during afternoon feeding on Friday, 10/18. On Saturday, 10/19, and Sunday, 10/20, the facility representatives did 
not observe the wolf during their daily observation checks. On Saturday, 10/19, the licensee determined Monday, 10/21, 
would be safer to enter the wolf enclosure to look closer for the wolf as the enclosure doesn't have a lockout for the 
remaining wolf and they would need a staff member to assist watching the remaining wolf while another person looked. 
On Monday morning, 10/21, the female wolf again was not seen and they still planned to look for it. During the inspection, 
the facility representatives reported they entered the enclosure, observing dens and checking the enclosure fence. They 
reported they didn't find the wolf and also walked the entire enclosure fence and did not find any areas that indicated it got 
out. We also observed around the entire enclosure and did not find any areas that would indicate escape. However, the 
second wolf was unable to be located. The facility representatives noted that there was an area in the center of the 
enclosure that could not be observed thoroughly without proper equipment or clearing some of the brush. At the time of 
the exit interview the licensee stated that 3 facility representatives were currently working on removing brush and looking 
for the second wolf.  
 
The lack of ability to confirm an animal's status with a daily observation of the animal doesn't guarantee if the animal is in 
good condition. Correct by ensuring enclosures are equipped with the ability to observe animals and/or coordinate with 
employees in a timely fashion to confirm that animals are in good health. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
SCOTT WELCH, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
